awd_titl_txt: EAPSI: Investigating Spinning Black Holes in a Modified Theory of Gravity
awd_abstract_narration:
Black holes behave very similarly to spinning tops when orbiting other black holes. This project will seek to understand this behavior in a modified theory of gravity called Chern-Simons gravity, where the gravitational interaction changes if the black holes are counter rotating to one another. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Takahiro Tanaka, who is an expert on the techniques used to describe spinning black holes, at Kyoto University. This project will further our understanding of the fundamental nature of gravity and how to test Einstein?s theory of General Relativity.

Dynamical Chern-Simons (dCS) gravity is a modified theory that alters the gravitational interaction through the introduction of parity violation. Such a modification only alters gravitating systems that are odd under reflection, such as spinning black holes. This project will study how the spins of black holes precess in dCS gravity when in binary systems, which will be encoded in the gravitational waves emitted by the system. The PI will collaborate with Kyoto University Professor Takahiro Tanaka, who helped pioneer techniques to describe the spin precession of black holes. The project is critical to further our understanding of how to perform model independent tests of Einstein's theory of General Relativity using gravitational waves where modifications only effect spinning systems.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

por.por_cntn:
The detection of gravitational waves by the Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory (LIGO) detectors has opened a new window to studying black holes. Observations of the gravitational waves from black hole binary systems have verified Einstein’s prediction of their existence and placed the some of the most stringent constraints on modifications from Einstein’s theory of gravity, General Relativity (GR). One modified theory of gravity, called dynamical Chern-Simons gravity, has proven difficult to constrain with such observations. The reason for this is that black holes are only different from GR in dCS gravity when they are spinning. When two spinning black holes exist in a binary system, their spins interact causing the amplitude of the gravitational waves produced by the binary to fluctuate. These fluctuations were not observed in the detections made by the LIGO detectors due to the signal being too short, and as a result, constraints could not be placed on dCS gravity. Future detectors and observations of long lived signals are expected to observe these fluctuations. However, if we seek to constrain the gravitational interaction between spinning objects, then we must first understand how these fluctuations encode information about the underlying nature of gravity.

 

This project seeks to understand the interaction of spinning black holes in dCS gravity and how they affect observed gravitational wave signals. To do this, a few ingredients are needed. The first is an effective description of the black holes. In dCS gravity, black holes have an additional property called a scalar dipole moment, which produces an additional gravitational field similar to the magnetic field produced by a bar magnet. The effective description takes this into account and provides the necessary coupling between the scalar dipole moment and the modified gravitational field. Analysis of this effective theory shows that the equations governing the dynamics of the black hole spins, referred to as the precession equations, are modified in two ways: one that couples the scalar dipoles of the black holes to the orbital angular momentum and one that couples the scalar dipole of one black hole to the spin of the other. These resemble the effects in GR that couple the spins of the two black holes to the orbital angular momentum and to each other, only with a weaker interaction.

 

The second ingredient needed for this computation is the gravitational field produced by the black hole binary. In GR, this field is described by how spacetime is curved due to the presence of the black holes and is well understood. In dCS gravity, this has been computed for isolated black holes, but not for binary systems. We have carried out this computation and have found that the strongest correction to curvature of spacetime comes from the interaction between the scalar dipoles of the two black holes. This induces a third type of correction into the precession equations, which is referred to as a spin-cubed correction since the scalar dipole moment is proportional to the black hole’s spin. This can be thought of as arising from the fact that the binary’s binding energy is modified compared to GR due to the interaction between the scalar dipole moments of the black holes. Of all the modifications to the precession equations, this is the strongest, but is still weaker compared to the effects from GR.

 

With the modified precession equations in hand, we will seek to obtain the solutions to the equations which provide the motion of the black hole spins as a function of time. Based off the structure of the equations, we expect the solutions to resemble those in GR, but with a modified precession frequency. Once such solutions are obtained, we will calculate how this alters the amplitude fluctuation of the gravitational waves produced by the black hole binary. Ultimately, this will affect our ability to constrain modified theories of gravity using gravitational wave observations by LIGO and the future Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA). This aids us in understanding the mechanisms that drove the evolution of the early universe and provides probes of the fundamental nature of the gravitational force.
